title: Tuesday, 15th August, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:01am

Hi there

PM11:01am

Who says nothing corporate happens in the middle of August in London??

PM11:01am

National Grid plc scrip dividend

National Grid confirms that an application has been made to the Financial Conduct Authority for 3,168,642 ordinary shares to be admitted to the Official List, and to the London Stock Exchange for the shares to be admitted to trading, in relation to the operation of the Scrip Dividend scheme for the 2016/17 final dividend, payable on 16 August 2017. Dealings are expected to commence on 16 August 2017 and the shares will rank pari passu with the existing issued ordinary shares of the Company.

11:01 am
PM11:01am

That's not quite fair actually

PM11:02am

There is news around

PM11:02am

We've even got a contested bid

11:02 am
PM11:02am

And there things like lots of Brexit stuff

PM11:02am

I've forgotten whether we are a Brexit free zone or not

PM11:02am

We havent mentioned in a while

11:02 am
PM11:03am

But is this customs union paper actually out yet?

PM11:03am

I can't see a copy

PM11:03am

Just the reports

11:03 am
PM11:03am

https://www.ft.com...-a4ce-15b2513cb3ff

PM11:03am

Which you can read -- or 'listen to'

PM11:04am

Actually, one person to definitely read on Brexit stuff is Malcolm Barr of JPM

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Always clear and sensible

PM11:04am

Let me get some

PM11:04am

According to press reports, the UK will today publish a paper on its proposed customs arrangements post Brexit. The UK will reportedly propose an “interim” customs union arrangement after Brexit while also seeking the right to negotiate new deals with third parties in that period. We will comment more when we see the substance of the paper. In advance of it, however, we want to restate a key point: frictionless trade in goods is not just about customs arrangements, but also about the regulatory convergence generated via the single market.

We have written about this before (see here). But let’s begin with some simple definitions in an attempt to keep things clear.

11:04 am
PM11:04am

The EU’s single market is the system of unified arrangements for the regulation of goods and services production in the EU. It attempts to ensure that the products themselves (in terms of the design, labelling, safety features, etc) and the conditions under which they are produced and distributed meet a harmonised standard. In many cases that standard may be drawn from international bodies. But the arrangements for implementation and monitoring compliance with those standards are then designed by the EU.

The EU’s custom union consists of three elements (a) a unified approach to trade with non-EU countries, (b) a unified code of administrative procedures for the passage of goods at the EU’s external and internal borders, and (c) the removal of tariffs on trade between EU members.

It is vital to recognise that the ‘frictionless’ trade the UK has with the EU as an EU member is dependent on all of the above. And examples of different constellations of the above already exist which demonstrate their importance.

PM11:05am

Members of the EEA, for example, are in the single market but do not have a “full” customs union agreement with the EU (Norway, Iceland and Lichtenstein). EU-EEA trade is tariff free, but relationships with third parties can differ. The result is that EEA exports to the EU are subject to customs procedures relating to the origin of goods, whereby tariffs may need to be paid when the third party content of goods is high.

Turkey is not “in” the EU customs union but has a bespoke customs union arrangement with the EU. Although that removes tariffs on Turkish goods exports to the EU, there are still lengthy procedures at the EU-Turkey border. These derive from the fact that Turkey is not in the single market – hence its goods exports need to be checked for compliance with EU standards, and Turkish freight carriers do not have an automatic entitlement to work in the EU, hence their permits need to be checked.

If the UK wants to sustain frictionless trade with the EU as seen until now, it will need to retain the regulatory convergence established via single market membership. Differing permutations of customs arrangements will not get around that.

PM11:05am

He's promising more when the actual paper gets published

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Rather than just commenting on the pre-briefings

PM11:05am

So we'll see

undefined
11:05 am
PM11:05am

What do you reckon Bryce?

BE11:06am

Well then.

PM11:06am

Footsie up a reasonable 30 points

11:06 am
PM11:06am

It's kinda mixed

BE11:06am

FTSE's up on sterling, which is post inflation data, which is a really really really really really really really really really really really really dull thing to talk about.

BE11:07am

Instead, we have an early request in for Next.

11:07 am
Next PLC (NXT:LSE): Last: 4,226, down 169 (-3.85%), High: 4,341, Low: 4,186, Volume: 279.06k
BE11:07am

Which is on a Berenberg downgrade.

PM11:08am

Saying Sell

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Yup. Familiar arguments, but very nicely written.

PM11:08am

As ever with Berenberg

PM11:08am

Nicely written that is

11:08 am
BE11:08am

All based around the business school standard of the Kodak moment.

BE11:08am

As in, Next is protecting its market into obsolescence.

BE11:09am

Same way Kodak did with cheap cameras and expensive film. Next is doing it with expensive shops and .... trousers and ...... um .... hang on, let me retrace.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

The general idea here is that Next's lost its way.

BE11:10am

BE11:10am

And has too many actual shops.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

When sales, to state the obvious, are moving online.

PM11:10am

hmm

BE11:11am

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Which'd be fine if Next had retained its edge for online, but it hasn't.

BE11:12am

Partly on the free delivery side of things, but also on the need to run it as something other than hire-purchase for court appearance suits.

BE11:12am

Berenberg's exec sum looks like this:

11:12 am
BE11:12am

The 10% rally in Next’s share price following the weather-driven Q2 beat provides material downside. As such, we downgrade to Sell with a price target of GBp3,650. We believe Next is burdened by its overspaced store estate, which restricts its ability to invest in areas that matter most to the consumer – product and free home delivery, leading to market share erosion. While it was quick to recognise the online opportunity, it has failed to fully adapt its business model, instead focusing on short-term cash flow and profitability. We believe offering free home delivery could reduce EBIT margin by c5ppt in the near term, but is ultimately necessary to maintain market share.

BE11:13am

Recent results are weather, they say. Pay more attention to the trend.

BE11:13am

Over the past 10 years, Next’s store revenues have increased by 2%, while space has increased by 71%. We believe management’s current strategy is formulated to maximise short-term returns, rather than adapting to ensure longer-term survival. This is preventing Next from investing in areas that matter most to the consumer, in our view, leading to market share erosion.

11:13 am
BE11:14am

And it's getting out-Primarked.

BE11:14am

As sales have shifted online, the competitive advantages of a well-located store estate have diminished while product and price transparency have increased. Due to its slow and unresponsive supply chain, Next lacks the differentiated product offering needed to acquire customers, in our view. We believe this, together with a lack of free delivery, has contributed to a c16% decline in consumers’ perception of the value for money of the Next brand in the past three years.

BE11:15am

As in, Primark has a stunningly fast turnover of stuff. Next doesn't.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

And finally, Directory is looking like yesterday's tomorrow.

BE11:15am

Though it was quick to recognise the shift of sales online, we believe Next now lags peers due to its failure to offer free home delivery, among other things. We estimate that home delivery revenues have declined by c6% pa. While historically, this decline has been more than offset by an increase in click-and-collect orders, this is no longer the case. With c92% of consumers now preferring home delivery, we believe UK Directory growth will remain challenging for Next as management continues to protect margins. Offering free home delivery would be painful in the short term, diluting Directory EBIT margin by c5ppt, but it is essential to adapt to changing consumer demands, in our view.

BE11:16am

So, sell.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

As I say, we've seen the argument a lot in recent years that Next's gone from well run cash machine to structurally disadvantaged laggard, but it's rarely expressed so neatly within 24 pages.

PM11:17am

That's pretty comprehensive

PM11:17am

And quite a call

11:17 am
PM11:17am

Given the longer term history of this stock

BE11:17am

Actually, just as a postscript, I was just scanning the bumf of the note .....

BE11:17am

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Is that right? The PRC has 1% of Next?

PM11:18am

Ha!

BE11:18am

It'd be below the disclosure boundary, so I guess it might be from a US filing somewhere then picked up via a newswire scraper.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

News to me though. If anyone can enlighten us if, how, or why, PRC has 1% of Next, please go ahead.

PM11:20am

Can't see them listed on the Eikon page

BE11:21am

(@Bluesky21: Primark's not online at all. That's their model, and it's worked very well for them, but it's a niche that seems to work right across the high street only when you're charging prices sufficiently low to drag people out of bed on a Saturday morning.)

11:21 am
undefined
PM11:22am

This bars battle

PM11:22am

Revolution

11:22 am
PM11:22am

https://www.invest...1708150700049767N/

11:22 am

PM11:23am

PM11:24am

11:24 am
BE11:24am

BE11:24am

All of which I'm sure are great, in their own way, but I can't speak from experience.

BE11:25am

(Actually, I might've been to Atik in Edinburgh. That's theirs.)

11:25 am
PM11:25am

I used to work in a nightclub in Portsmouth

PM11:25am

Had to knock the fag buts out of the plastic pint pots before pouring beer

PM11:26am

Had a foghorn on the bar for whenever a fight broke out

11:25 am

It was actually too dangerous to leavel the bar

PM11:26am

BE11:26am

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Deltic believes that a combination of its business with Revolution would transform the scalability of the enlarged group, provide scope for material synergies and enable the operational issues within Revolution to be better addressed through Deltic's management team taking responsibility for both businesses, creating a powerhouse group in its sector that can exploit further opportunities to both expand and consolidate the market.

BE11:27am

Though it has to, as its pitch is "stronger together" rather than "here, have some cash".

BE11:27am

has proposed to Revolution that they explore on an expedited timescale an all share merger subject to negotiation of appropriate merger terms, reciprocal due diligence and Revolution shareholder approval, a transaction which would be effected through an acquisition of Deltic by Revolution using Revolution shares as consideration.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

And the history of listed nightclub operators means it's fair enough for investors to be a bit cautious about that.

BE11:28am

Deltic was of course Luminar, which collapsed.

PM11:28am

Ah, right

11:29 am

The old names seem to be abandoned as well. Liquid, Lava, Ignite ...

BE11:30am

Anyway, the last time around Luminar collapsed due to student spending ......

BE11:31am

Eclectic Clubs & Bars has hit trouble on exactly the same trend. And so, as it happens, has Revolution.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Not entirely sure how sticking a student-exposed bar chain together with a nightclub-exposed bar chain makes for a more stable company. Stonegate's moeny's probably safer, I'd have thought.

PM11:32am

Mears Group PLC (MER:LSE): Last: 445.25, down 39.75 (-8.20%), High: 452.50, Low: 430.00, Volume: 62.72k
BE11:35am

Public work dropped off post Grenfell, they say.

11:35 am
PM11:35am

Not surprised

BE11:35am

Clients reviewing safety practices.

PM11:35am

As well they should

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Order book unchanged, Mears reckons, but timelines getting pushed back.

BE11:36am

We're looking at downgrades in towards the high single digits, by the looks of it.

BE11:36am

Here's Jefferies' first cut of the numbers.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

nterim EPS of 13.98p was in line with management expectations, but 10% below our estimates (15.4p), driven by weaker margins. Housing growth was 3% (JEFe: 5%, 2H16: 8%) with margins +40bps to 5.2% (JEFe: 5.6%). Order intake was £105m (1H16 £259M), and the win rate declined to 30% (1H16 39%). Care growth was -10% (JEFe: -12%, 2H16: -7%) with EBITA of -£1m (JEFe: -£0.7m). Order intake was £97M, with a win rate of 64% (1H16 77%). Cash conversion was weak at 70%, due to working capital (target: 90%). The outlook statement comments that the Grenfell Tower fire is impacting commissioning decisions, and there are likely to be temporary procurement delays. In addition, Housing margins are expected to be 5.3-5.5%, down from 5.6-5.8%. Subsequently, we expect mid-to-high single digit downgrades to FY17F EPS. (Consensus 33.6p). The shares trade on 12x PE.

BE11:38am

Liberum's house so says nothing much. Peel Hunt does a little more.

BE11:39am

Trading details. H117 revenues rose 1% to £470.8m (PHe £480.0m) with PBT rising 1% to £18.3m (PHe £18.1m). Social Housing (98% FY17 EBITA) reported 3% organic revenue growth to £402m reflecting the momentum from new contract wins in 2016. H117 EBITA margin increased to 5.2% (PHe: 5.2%) from 4.8% and drives a 10% improvement in EBITA to £20.8m (PHe £21.5m). This reflects the evolving mix shift to Housing Management, increased pension service costs (flagged at prelims c£1.5m H1 impact) and a normalisation of bidding costs (PHe: £2.0m). The pipeline remains attractive (expect to bid £0.9-1.0bn in 2017) and the win rate remains encouraging at 30% (by value). As expected, Care (2% FY17 EBITA) reported a £1.0m loss (PHe: loss £1.0m). This reflects the challenging market (carer recruitment and retention) as well as the withdrawal from c30% of hours (over last 12 months) as part of the ongoing Care refocus (cost taken above the line). However, the rightsizing, underlying trading patterns, mix shift towards output based contract and win rates (at improving pricing) underpins a profitable H2 outlook. H1 net debt of £19.6m (average net debt £85m), reflects a rolling 12-month EBITDA conversion slightly below 70%. Although weaker than historical norms, management confidently reiterated the greater than 90% goal for 2017.

11:39 am
BE11:40am

Estimates. Management believes that the tragic events at Grenfell Tower are likely to impact the timing of certain planned maintenance activity as clients ensure that their housing portfolios are safe and fully compliant. Management guidance is for a £30m revenue impact (we still anticipate YoY organic revenue growth) but we expect a £4.0m EBITA impact to £43.0m (-2% YoY) given the profit and overhead recovery impact. We reduce our Dec 2017 PBT from £44.0m to £40.0m to give EPS of 30.3p from 33.4p. We conservatively assume some flow through to 2018 and we reduce FY18 PBT by £2m to give PBT of £48m and EPS of 36.2p. Management’s longer-term outlook is positive and we retain our 2019 estimates. It is also notable that there is no change to our Care assumptions as visibility improves through the bidding discipline and self-help actions.

BE11:40am

Valuation. On our revised estimates, the shares are on 13.4x Dec 2018, FCF yield 5.5% and yield 2.9% (2.6x covered). Looking forward and beyond the near-term market hiatus, the rating does not reflect the opportunity to drive superior, visible cash-backed growth through this leading management team. We remain positive and believe the longer-term outlook is strengthening, not diminishing.

BE11:41am

Just looking through the numbers. They do a 5.2% operating margin on housing, which seems reasonably low.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Though that's perhaps because the smaller, more local building maintenance companies operate in a borderline criminal way.

BE11:43am

As in, colluding with freeholders to gouge tenants. Tricky market to be in for that reason.

undefined
11:43 am
PM11:43am

Hargreaves Landsdown

PM11:43am

I thought these figures were good

PM11:43am

But there's no share price reaction

11:44 am
PM11:44am

Stock's unchanged at 1363

PM11:44am

Finals here https://www.invest...1708150700049801N/

BE11:44am

The numbers, as you say, are fine. What happens next is all that matters though.

11:44 am
PM11:45am

Ah, did we miss the FCA forcing an announcement on capital last week?

PM11:45am

Seems so

BE11:45am

Yes, that happened. Fourth I think.

11:45 am
PM11:45am

So these numbers were a surprise to no one

BE11:46am

The capital requirement thing removed the possibility of a special div, so made the immediate term for Hargreaves kinda dull. All you're left with is a load of new competition and a bunch of regulation, which might or might not be in the price already.

BE11:46am

Numis says it isn't.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

The key data points of the FY 2017 results were an AuA increase of 28% to £79.2bn with a 15% increase in net inflows to £6.9bn driving a 21% increase in profit to £265.8m which was 3% ahead of consensus. We believe that there is a strong growth outlook for HL with continued substantial net inflows and the potential for HL savings to provide another substantial leg for growth. Given the better than expected results, particularly the net AuA inflows, we upgrade our pre-tax profit forecast for this year by 7% to £306.4m and by 3% next year to £341.1m. Given the passing of a special dividend, and that regulatory capital requirements only ever seem to increase we expect HL to distribute 85% of profit going forwards, continually boosting the group's capital strength. Consequently, we have adjusted our DCF valuation so that only 85% of expected profits are valued. Based on our dividend forecasts for this year HL has an attractive 3.6% dividend yield.

BE11:48am

Morgan Stanley says it is. And also has a short complain about Hargreaves' new reporting regime.

BE11:48am

Limited surprise from today's results, given numbers pre-
released 4 Aug. Adjusting for one-off gains, PBT is in-line,
though platform margins are lower than expected. Moves into
wealth management could provide new growth, but new
reporting is less helpful for investors, with little divisional
detail.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Broadly speaking Hargreaves operates two distinct businesses, a direct to consumer platform (Vantage) and an advisory business (PMS & Multi manager). Historically the firm has provided detailed revenue, AUM disclosure and KPIs on these two parts. Going forward, reporting will be merged. The fewer line items will make it harder for investors to analyse the moving parts of the business, which appears a step back to us, particularly given plans to exploit the large opportunity in private wealth.

BE11:49am

I guess in terms of news the Hargreaves story is the flagging up of weaker margins from 2018, but that seems to have surprised no one.

BE11:50am

Have a seller as well, just for the full spread of opinion. Citigroup.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

HL has ambitions for further growth: it notes its 38% market share of the execution only UK D2C platform market, but “a much smaller share” of the £1.1 trillion investment market and £2.4 trillion savings and investment pool. At 28x FY18E PE for 12% EPS CAGR FY17-19E, it needs to deliver on this ambition. Sell.

undefined
BE11:51am

@JuB, nothing on Worldpay that's passed by us this morning.

11:52 am
PM11:52am

Another deal that was sealed while we were away

BE11:52am

The history of Worldpay Emma Dunkley did last week's worth your time: https://www.ft.com...12a6e743000486aec8

BE11:53am

.......... and there's been various brokers pushing a "global leader" type idea, including Stifel and Exane. But not this morning, so we don't waste your time with those.

11:53 am
BE11:54am

Instead, we'll waste your time with ...... Shire, maybe?

Shire PLC (SHP:LSE): Last: 3,861, up 68 (+1.79%), High: 3,880, Low: 3,810, Volume: 696.33k
PM11:54am

Dry eye disease stuff

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Also, SocGen pushing.

BE11:54am

We haven’t witnessed a more irrational pricing since the patent cliff. Although that period was frustrating, it was also ephemeral. And the investors who got the story then were well rewarded. We find the current share price ex ADHD implies a 25-50% discount to peers and a double-digit annual percentage decline in cash flows into perpetuity. We haven’t seen a relative valuation this low since the patent cliff. BUY.

BE11:55am

We think the recent share price weakness (-7% in 1 month) indicates that investors are anticipating a destruction of value from Shire’s potential exit from ADHD. But even in the worst case, with an ADHD spin-off (i.e. no monetisation, with no debt on ADHD’s books, trough multiples and no perpetuity value), we calculate that Shire’s current share price is so low as to imply that the remaining (highly valuable) Rare Disease (RD) business is unsustainable. This is just irrational. In this worst case (which, however, eliminates the 2023 Vyvanse patent expiry issue), even if Roche’s ACE910 (phase 3) disrupts Shire’s haemophilia non-inhibitor franchise (and high-profile precedents suggest it won’t), Shire’s other RD franchises and pipeline will still stand to deliver sustainable growth and in our view should easily be able to pay off the existing debt pile. Apart from a compelling valuation, we have to ask why investors can’t see the multi-sourced, above-average, front-loaded EPS growth and upside surprise potential that we can?

11:56 am
BE11:56am

So, numbers come back a bit based on Roche taking some share and generics coming in for Lialda, which does gutrot IIRC.

BE11:57am

However, it's more than in the price, SocGen says.

BE11:57am

SHP is an outlier on sector regression analyses based on both our – but more importantly, also on consensus – estimates as many investors appear to believe that it is a value trap (and it has no yield support) or they have lost faith in its long-term growth prospects. Our TP still averages the 2017-19e EV/EBITA multiples (£63) and a DCF (£87). We value ADHD at £10 by applying patent cliff multiples and at £9 via a DCF that assumes no perpetuity value. Our RD valuations of £53 (EV/EBITA) and £78/share (DCF) imply a discount to the Baxalta peer group and a 1% perpetuity growth rate, respectively. In all, our TP remains £75 as the cut in our SOP inputs (lower near-term earnings and target multiple) offset the rise in our DCF from a higher probability of success of SHP643 and first-time inclusion of SHP647, soon to enter phase 3.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

(@wayneJ: I've had dozens of conversations about how MifidII will affect both us and those we speak to each day, and with each conversation I become less clear about how anything will actually work in practice. We might as well just wait and see.)

undefined
PM11:59am

Thanks for all that Bryce

11:59 am
PM12:00pm

Shall we end with some crypto nonsense?

PM12:00pm

This has just dropped in my inbox

BE12:00pm

If we must.

12:00 pm
PM12:00pm

Seratio Platform ICO

PM12:00pm

1st ICO in UK regulatory framework

PM12:01pm

About CCEG
The Centre for Citizenship Enterprise and Governance (CCEG) is the world’s leading think tank on the movement of value. Established in the UK with academic networks across Europe, Asia and the Americas, we have developed a vision for a Circular Economy based on Values. Since 2011, our experts have provided financial and non-financial metrics which underpin global legislation and have become internationally recognised as a standard.
This is the first issue of a resilient Ethereum token, compliant to UK regulatory frameworks. Fundraising will fulfil the foundation and infrastructure to deliver the vision of Cryptocurrencies with Values. Planned connected coins will grow market adoption, including the already commissioned Women’s Coin, City Coin, Faith Coin, Edu Coin Leadership Coin and other UN Sustainable Development Goals.
The unique feature of the Seratio token is the ability to capture the financial assets, microshares and provenance of transactions involving people, products, processes, projects and organisations.

London – New York – Shanghai

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Hm.

PM12:01pm

a Circular Economy based on Values.

BE12:01pm

Meanwhile, from the bulge brokers, Morgan Stanley has something out today pointing out that in any comparison of bitcoin vs gold you have to take account of the fact that bitcoins aren't actually "mined" so aren't really a commodity.

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

Not sure how many investors needed told that, but there we are.

PM12:02pm

I've found the 'office' where this Seratio token -- creating a circular world economy -- is based

PM12:02pm

12:02 pm
PM12:03pm

Centre for Citizenship, Enterprise and Governance
Bureau 112 UN Innovation
Green Street
Northampton, Northamptonshire NN1 1SY
United Kingdom

PM12:03pm

Google it yourself

undefined
12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Before we knock off, Danone mentioned on the right.

BE12:04pm

Which has been one of those slow build stories. Feels like we've been having conversations for months about how people feel in their gripe waters that Danone is the next target.

BE12:05pm

The latest development to that end is Corvex buying nearly no shares and wanting nearly nothing in exchange.

12:04 pm
BE12:05pm

"improving operations"

BE12:05pm

and "position the business in Health and Wellness"

BE12:05pm

Which, one could argue, is what Danone's doing anyway.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

As in, 16% margin target by 2020

BE12:06pm

And that fake milk acquisition.

BE12:07pm

You've also got history here. Nelson Peltz getting in at the back end of 2012 and exiting less than six months later, having achieved very little.

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

Here's JP Morgan.

BE12:07pm

In our view Danone’s issues are structurally impacted by
the drop in consumption of yoghurts in developed markets while we caution that a similar fate may await WWAV categories after years of expansion of plant-based milk in the USA. Higher margin targets (beyond the 16% already announced) as well as a possible call for a break-up of the company may be the potential end game for Corvex, but these are unlikely to resonate with Danone’s board or its management in our view.

BE12:08pm

Danone trades at c18.3x PE ’18E and 12.4x EV/EBITDA ’18E, a c7% discount to EU/US Food sector.

12:09 pm
PM12:09pm

(doeswalk -- so it's a new build. Fair enough. Buyers of crypto are still wingnuts.)

BE12:10pm

See also the New York Post article yesterday, which was deeply speculative, and the various bits of sellside from the likes of Bernstein, Exane and Kepler to have speculated about potential Danone buyers.

BE12:10pm

As in, Kraft/3G or Pepsi. Probably not Coke.

12:10 pm
BE12:10pm

Beyond that, we know nothing. Zero. Nil. But that's it noted anyway.

undefined
PM12:11pm

Cheers Bryce

12:11 pm
PM12:11pm

Thanks for joining us on the right

PM12:11pm

Bryce is back tomorrow, but I'm not

BE12:11pm

Omg smile
